conversation.content: [short pause] So you're the new shift lead everyone's talking about?

[jealous] That's me—though I wouldn't say "everyone." More like... three people in accounting and whoever's been reading the bulletin board by the break room. Started last Monday; already memorized every SKU in the warehouse.
Every single one?

Four thousand, two hundred and thirty-seven unique items. The trick is creating mental maps—aisle by aisle, shelf by shelf—turning numbers into spatial memories. Your brain's better at remembering locations than arbitrary codes.
That's impossible.

[shy] Not impossible, just... disciplined. I spend my lunch breaks walking the floor, touching boxes, whispering product codes like mantras. People think I'm weird—they're not wrong—but efficiency ratings don't lie.
How long have you been doing this?
Warehouse work? Seven years. Leadership? Three months. Before this I was at the distribution center downtown—bigger operation, worse management. Here feels more... human-scaled.
[anxious] Are you going to change everything around here?

Change? No. Optimize? Absolutely. Small adjustments—shift rotations that match circadian rhythms, break schedules that prevent fatigue spikes. Nothing revolutionary; just paying attention to how bodies actually work.
[extremely happy] That actually sounds amazing!

[slurring] The data supports it—productivity increases when people aren't fighting their own biology. We're not machines; we're organisms with peaks and valleys. Work with the valleys, not against them.
Where'd you learn all this?
Night school, mostly. Industrial psychology, some ergonomics, a bit of operations research. Plus YouTube—endless rabbit holes about optimization theory while eating cereal at 2 AM.
You studied while working full time?
Four years of it. Classes Tuesday-Thursday, homework on breaks, papers written between truck unloadings. Coffee became a food group. Worth it though—knowledge compounds like interest.
[happy] I'm actually excited to work with you.
Good. Energy's contagious—positive or negative—it spreads through teams like temperature through metal. We keep the enthusiasm up, the whole shift benefits. Simple thermodynamics, really.
You relate everything to science?

Patterns exist everywhere—in box stacks, break room conversations, forklift routes. Once you start seeing the underlying structures, you can't unsee them. It's beautiful and maddening in equal measure.
